title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring they do not lose eligibility to accrue benefits. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring they do not lose eligibility to accrue benefits. Continued participation is deemed as service with the employer for determining nonforfeitability and benefit accrual. Earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liability and obligations of the plan. In a multiemployer plan, liabilities are allocated by the plan sponsor. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Liabilities in a multiemployer plan are allocated by the plan sponsor. The period of participation extends until the participant reaches normal retirement age or the end of the plan. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The participant can continue until reaching normal retirement age, the end of the plan, or failure to pay required contributions. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are responsible for funding plan obligations. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are liable for funding plan obligations, including employer and employee contributions. Voluntary employee contributions only accrue benefits for those who elect continued participation. The plan allows for benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions to be allocated to similarly situated beneficiaries after a qualifying event. The participant is deemed to have received compensation at the rate prior to the event, as if they had continued working 1,000 hours per year. Contributions made by the qualified beneficiary are limited during the period of continued participation. The plan limits contributions by the qualified beneficiary to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period of continued participation. Contributions can be made in monthly installments, and no payment is required before 45 days from the initial election. The election period begins before the qualifying event. The election period for continued participation in the plan begins before the qualifying event and lasts at least 90 days. Any qualified beneficiary's election includes other beneficiaries who would cease to be beneficiaries due to the qualifying event. The election period for continued participation in the plan lasts at least 90 days and includes an election for other qualified beneficiaries who would cease to be beneficiaries due to the qualifying event. An exception applies to defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees. Definitions for applicable contribution and qualified beneficiary are provided. Accruals attributable to the period of continued participation determined under regulations of the Secretary. Qualified beneficiary means any beneficiary under the plan before the qualifying event, including the participant in the case of a qualifying event described. Qualifying event means events within seven years of the participant's normal retirement age that would result in the cessation of benefit accruals of a qualified beneficiary. Termination or reduction of hours of the participant's employment are qualifying events. Qualifying events, within seven years of normal retirement age, would stop benefit accruals for a qualified beneficiary: termination or reduction of employment hours, and participant's death. The Act applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996, with a special rule for defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements, not applying before the termination of agreements or January 1, 2000.
